02D6B2BCD03F49E296B497C72BCF8303.description: describe the legal, social, and moral responsibilities of parents as outlined in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (e.g., providing adequate food, shelter, care, education)

045D34E91CEA4A0D8B219AA53F297DCA.description: identify community social programs and agencies that provide support to children and families (e.g., YMCA/YWCA, Big Brothers/Big Sisters, family shelters, Aboriginal Head Start programs, Kids Help Phone, Parenting and Family Literacy Centres)

440EFBA2618843ACB736F14B6C154FE7.description: demonstrate an understanding of the laws that regulate the behaviour of children and parents in society (e.g., provisions of the Child and Family Services Act of Ontario; laws regarding school attendance, child labour, and parental leave from work)

1CF1CFB239884BB99670261BAE29341B.description: describe the positive and negative roles of societal agents in the lives of young children (e.g., the role of schools in teaching children to "get along" with others, the role of religious institutions in instilling values, the role of media in shaping children's attitudes to violence)

B2499D6010B54A0F961432EFED8F0168.description: Society's Role in the Lives of Children and Families: describe the roles and responsibilities of society in protecting and supporting children and families, and the responsibilities of caregivers towards children.

2D016A5CB4AC4C0BB23F3B6042E15A41.description: identify various barriers parents face in gaining access to community supports (e.g., language, culture, level of literacy or education)

A9AB6099B0F344C58909AEFF83D8568B.description: demonstrate an understanding of the laws relating to child abuse and children's rights (e.g., the community's responsibility for children's welfare, the duty to report suspected child abuse)

31A0E2A6839647F2849228097889B1DB.description: describe strategies that can be used to secure a safe and peaceful family, community, and social environment for children (e.g., teaching children that "touch" should never be kept secret; teaching safe Internet practices; providing "streetproofing" training to children)

944024C12FF74D329825872937690DFC.description: describe indicators of possible neglect or physical, sexual, or emotional abuse (e.g., malnutrition, lack of trust, unexplained bruises)

00847D567ED843D1B869948246EBB083.description: Neglect and Abuse: describe strategies for building healthy family relationships in order to prevent neglect and/or physical, sexual, or emotional abuse of children;

ACAAFEB083C14CF7A49D94960DCF2771.description: identify and describe challenges associated with teenage parenthood and lone parenting (e.g., poverty, discrimination, lack of gender-role modelling, stress)

56CD7EE5F4984501B8504DFA20D7CF8E.description: identify indicators of possible mental illness or mental health problems in young children (e.g., social withdrawal, unexplained fears)

D7C64EF66D1A4227937DB87D9FE04CBC.description: identify the unique challenges faced by families when parents or children have disabilities or special needs (e.g., a parent in a wheelchair, a child with autism)

9CED59C8AEE444B19C5F9E42094402B6.description: identify strategies used by families to manage different types of early-childhood trauma

A08D42BF7F8D4A5D94917A8FE09E2057.description: demonstrate an understanding of the challenges faced by parents of young children in today's rapidly changing society (e.g., balancing work and family responsibilities, finding quality childcare, dealing with discrimination)

88EB77F3718D4C1EB3EF15AB6992FAD4.description: summarize the lifestyle and relationship changes that parents experience when raising young children (e.g., decreasing independence, fatigue, shifting priorities, varying rewards of caregiving, changing responsibilities as the child ages)

929FE993D715426DA2C2153D7A289BA0.description: Caregiving Challenges in the Early Years: demonstrate an understanding of the challenges facing parents throughout the early childhood years;

D74E6D8954CE43CAACC5E0FDB340D0EC.description: compare expectations for male and female children in their own and other cultures

0780B90B9B514CA8BCE3341CB6A66BE9.description: describe how childhood experiences vary/have varied in different cultures and historical periods (e.g., variations in levels of freedom and/or adult supervision for children in different times and places; variations in the age at which children start school and/or work in different times, places, or cultures)

E4A07E01E5D04C059B4CE45DF1DB4911.description: identify forms of children's play that are found in all societies/cultures (e.g., traditional games involving balls and sticks, games modelled on "tag", variations of "playing house")

5D91A678E9234761824AC20E04CE7773.description: Common and Diverse Experiences of Childhood: demonstrate an understanding of common and diverse experiences of young children in a variety of cultures and historical periods.

B83E7F5F2AC94047B0419F22FE61B5D4.description:
describe ways in which parents and family
members teach children socially acceptable
behaviour (e.g., by encouraging good table manners
at family meal time, by encouraging sharing with playmates)

A1EA9F0B407E473BAAEB4BAE56F20D46.description: describe ways in which a parent can act as a positive role model for children (e.g., by modelling environmental responsibility, showing respect and care for others, having a positive body image)

60E45B3B95144CCABE463CC67698788D.description: demonstrate an understanding of strategies for encouraging positive behaviour in children (e.g., offering choices, discussing logical and natural consequences of behaviour)

DD66F2AA74814DF38317B55B976598A2.description: demonstrate an understanding of the importance of positive parenting strategies for the development of a child's self-esteem and self-discipline

ED56133B94FD4E8CA658429C973EE71F.description: describe different parenting styles (e.g., permissive, authoritarian, authoritative, indulgent) and assess how they affect young children

CE179EB53CA043ACA5EB9B465B35349C.description: Parenting Styles and Practices: demonstrate an understanding of a variety of child-rearing practices and their effects on children;

EA8679506A7D4AAFB6A5DC12C5B66A5F.description: describe ways in which culture and family tradition influence child-rearing practices (e.g., practices related to name selection, touch and physical contact, fostering cultural pride and a positive sense of self)

542EA661E42F493193B0FCC98C5A6A10.description: describe ways in which families transmit their cultural and religious heritage to children (e.g., through storytelling, visual arts, festivals, religious and other rituals) as well as the ways in which families may be constrained in their ability to transmit their culture and religion

0186C71D59A547F089A72899BC159B14.description: identify the functions of the family and explain how these functions may be carried out through a variety of family forms (e.g., same-sex couples with children, lone-parent families)

91650DF76C0A4E33B22CB588ED9ACC36.description: analyse their own personal understanding of the terms family and parent, and assess the possible biases that may be inherent in this understanding

464517CA838845559A04263BFD51C2E5.description: Family Variations: demonstrate an understanding of social and cultural variations in family forms and child-rearing approaches;

F066CA1039FB476586375BE14BA3D3E0.description: assess their own experience with infants and children and reflect on personal strengths and areas for improvement

A14B51A4337048BA8A8D176EFF3A3F19.description: demonstrate an understanding of an infant's needs and schedules by participating in a baby-simulation experience

DDCDDDE9ECC34C39A5BAE556B1E73018.description: demonstrate the ability to plan, organize, and carry out age-appropriate activities for children from birth to six years of age

C03C17687B4442528EB5F63F1E853BAE.description: explain differences they observe in the capabilities and behaviours of children of different ages in classroom and/or community settings

44CE7EA2628E403AB62CB13056FEF00B.description: describe the capabilities and behaviours of young children of different ages in real-life settings (e.g., at preschool, at home with their family, when with a babysitter)

F2639F77942A47669E8B65546CDFD8E2.description: Applying Child-Rearing Knowledge and Skills: apply and assess their child-rearing knowledge and skills through practical experiences with children.

7C1C4A9A4C0A45059C02CE0EC2065C15.description: demonstrate the ability to use age-appropriate reading materials effectively to promote the development of literacy skills in children

FE74602F0FBC4E9C8C73E04071802F43.description: demonstrate the use of supportive and considerate communication and conflictresolution skills (e.g., use of eye contact, active listening, "I" messages, encouragement)

E8A7F43B8AFC4758A03228D0A5B75470.description: demonstrate an understanding of ageappropriate verbal and non-verbal communication techniques (e.g., reading infant and toddler cues, using infant-directed talk, modelling appropriate language for older children)

FB6696D7FD1E4D41A6270553C619F88F.description: Communicating With Young Children: demonstrate an understanding of strategies parents can use to ensure effective communication in their families;

22EB075E52FB48009D99A3A6AEDF3E15.description: describe ways in which parents can reduce the environmental impact of raising children (e.g., using cloth diapers, breastfeeding, using homemade baby food, using public transit, choosing a fuel-efficient vehicle)

A6275F8BB1DC4C028E3CFA49226959BC.description: demonstrate the ability to plan their finances to provide for the care of an infant and/or young child (e.g., budget for the financial impact of a period of parental leave, the costs of a crib and layette)

32687FC4BEC646A394025CD80CB919D4.description: identify the personal qualities, skills, and attitudes that are necessary for parenting (e.g., patience, sense of humour, responsiveness, boundary-setting skills, consistency)

B72C79C174914280A9DC3FDC107016F5.description: evaluate the effectiveness of various methods for contraception and the prevention of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) (e.g., abstinence; barrier methods – male and female condoms, diaphragm, sponge; hormonal methods – oral contraceptives, injectable contraceptives, transdermal patch, vaginal ring; intrauterine device)

136B8C07CAFC4E1EB368EB57E78F202B.description: explain the importance of having healthy, supportive relationships with other adults when providing care to young children (e.g., as a source of information, for physical and emotional support)

6E0027D0BD224CD4B8AAD248FB91EDD0.description: explain why child rearing is a lifelong commitment in our society

01C508C6FCCC4A35B8221F655E1AF0D5.description: identify personal and cultural reasons for becoming parents (e.g., to build a family, to save a relationship, to “be like” one’s friends, to provide a loving home to a child whose birth parents are not able to provide care, to pass on one’s family name)

61A69BF7CAE4484191AAEE71A59AB270.description: identify the factors involved in deciding to become a parent (e.g., social pressures, cultural influences, physical and emotional maturity, values, economic stability, fertility)

08F493C48DFC4DE1B7BF1119D4C8B068.description: Preparing for Parenting: demonstrate an understanding of how to prepare for the responsibilities of being a parent;

DBA6D9DC8A544F4A8ED19BF06E598A2A.description: Personal and Social Responsibilities of Parents

877F558B9D0D4A4D99AB9F28991AF08C.description: describe the beneficial effects of healthy eating patterns on the growth and development of children from birth to six years of age (e.g., increased ability to concentrate, fewer common childhood illnesses, improved overall health)

6C8FAF2976DF412097108C29AD1ED7A3.description: plan nutritious meals and snacks for children of different ages based on Canadian food guidelines and regulations

1ABF53DDEE6B44DBAA4E454C5336EB03.description: identify ways in which partners and/or support persons can participate in infant care and support breastfeeding mothers (e.g., bathing the infant, changing diapers, bottle feeding the infant with pumped breast milk when the mother is unavailable)

42B84E6EDEC347F7945224995325AFA9.description: explain the unique importance of breastfeeding for the health of the baby, the birth mother, and the family (e.g., its role in meeting infant nutritional needs, preventing obesity, reducing the risk of breast cancer, promoting mother-infant bonding)

F59FD1F362D045059955D54479821F88.description: Infant and Child Nutrition: demonstrate an understanding of the importance of nutrition for healthy development.

815C62360B2846D5B60070E6026D8707.description: outline strategies parents can use to communicate with young children about their bodies (e.g., using proper names for all body parts, providing accurate information when answering questions about reproduction)

9D5A8BCAE7154BF99C13DAAEF233C316.description: explain the importance of play for healthy child development

96E6E88BB85544E298F0BC4EDFD45398.description: explain ways in which development from conception to six years of age significantly affects development later in life (e.g., explain the importance of early secure attachment for emotional health in adulthood; explain the connection between selfregulation in early childhood and later emotional and physical health)

CEBB4E66A2A04A27B7898923F1CF28B1.description: describe a variety of measures parents can take to ensure the physical safety of children from birth to six years of age (e.g., using car seats, supervising bath time, teaching children how to swim, using sunscreen, washing fruits and vegetables well)

D0558F57E32746D8BA9FF31389E9D561.description: describe strategies used by parents to enhance the social, emotional, cognitive, linguistic, and physical development of children from birth to six years of age

EDCD2AC25910432885522529246F2473.description: identify major milestones in the social, emotional, cognitive, linguistic, and physical development of children from birth to six years of age

C963D97114A84759B7F5CDD3C07382A5.description: Growth and Development: Stages and Influences: describe patterns in the healthy, social, emotional, cognitive, linguistic, and physical development of young children;

2E825C190A844244B4F2A5F6CD209E4C.description: describe ways in which partners and/or support persons can contribute to a healthy pregnancy (e.g., attending prenatal classes, helping to prepare healthy food for the pregnant woman)

5A0C76330E9745F6B856AA36BAEFD9D7.description: describe the effects of teratogens and environmental hazards on prenatal and long-term development (e.g., fetal alcohol spectrum disorder, low birth weight, brain damage, premature birth), and identify strategies for avoiding exposure to teratogens and environmental hazards (e.g., avoiding cat feces; checking with a physician before taking any medications; avoiding recreational drugs and alcohol; avoiding exposure to toxic cleaning products, household and garden chemicals, paints and solvents, and insecticides on fruits and vegetables)

FC32BB868DDF4A0E8D09CFDA293A9F2E.description: identify and explain the importance of strategies for maintaining maternal and paternal health prior to and during pregnancy, birth, and the postnatal period (e.g., avoiding first-hand and second-hand smoke, having a healthy diet and getting adequate exercise, updating vaccinations, limiting stress, visiting their health care provider regularly, watching for signs of postpartum depression)

AF730AEB313F4033AA499B72AF8C1FEE.description: identify various hereditary and genetic factors that influence fetal development (e.g., sex-linked diseases, the Rh factor, chromosomal abnormalities, sex)

4A00EE0E59EB4A4780906A708A9E1405.description: identify appropriate prenatal and postnatal care and support programs and facilities that are available for parents in their community (e.g., prenatal classes, breastfeeding clinics, Native friendship centres, Ontario early years centres, Canadian Down Syndrome Society)

20C7400C4BA94679B912348836F3F767.description: outline the stages in the biological process of conception, pregnancy, and birth

7BE5F9CD34C1450CA9175D165EEBFCB3.description: Pregnancy, Birth, and Postnatal Care: describe factors that contribute to the healthy development of children before and during birth, and in the first few months after birth;

00D25C3166714AA99003DAF2ACE6FEE4.description: demonstrate an understanding of the general research process by reflecting on and evaluating their own research, inquiry, and communication skills

A70A017521884300BD1EFD65B0B5059E.description: clearly communicate the results of their inquiries (e.g., write clearly, organize ideas logically, use language conventions properly), and follow APA conventions for acknowledging sources (e.g., generate a reference list in APA style)

FEB6AD8952234CADA8A26D9704610CFD.description: use terms relating to the study of child development and child rearing correctly (e.g., cognitive development, physical development, logical and natural consequences, authoritative, authoritarian, permissive)

E7A8334864E049EDA677A2B49FA22FE1.description: use an appropriate format (e.g., oral presentation, brochure, poster, report, multimedia presentation, web page) to communicate the results of their research and inquiry effectively for a specific purpose and audience

B872EBF16D7E49209940EC2037A5DDD6.description: Communicating and Reflecting: communicate the results of their research and inquiry clearly and effectively, and reflect on and evaluate their research, inquiry, and communication skills.

1B152BD4EC3044138411A934CB9442B2.description: synthesize findings and formulate conclusions (e.g., determine whether their results support or contradict their hypothesis; weigh and connect information to determine the answer to their research questions)

03A315E0CD4F4170A23135F50EEE7549.description: demonstrate academic honesty by documenting the sources of all information gathered through research

852B2F84933540F4A8801127E66E1334.description: analyse and interpret research information (e.g., compare information gathered from surveys and interviews; determine whether similar information is found in different sources)

8A17E494DF544AC7A5585565E146B89E.description: record and organize information and key ideas using a variety of formats (e.g., notes, graphic organizers, summaries, audio/digital records)

894C8378801348959B0EDD5FE5B96286.description: assess various aspects of information gathered from primary and secondary sources (e.g., accuracy, relevance, reliability, inherent values and bias, voice)

093C50E1206C42D8B0D678F3FEE9D190.description: Processing Information: assess, record, analyse, and synthesize information gathered through research;

01CDEE4C72C1426A9248713C4A6E08BF.description: based on preliminary research, for each investigation formulate a hypothesis, thesis statement, or research question, and use it to focus their research

E379361F08B4494A84205CD166B6E58E.description: locate and select information relevant to their investigations from a variety of primary sources (e.g., interviews, observations, surveys, questionnaires, data sets from Statistics Canada) and/or secondary sources (e.g., book reviews, textbooks, websites, advertisements, brochures, newspaper and magazine articles)

545E862BB9AA45C38E9DB16158D8B25B.description: create appropriate research plans to investigate their selected topics (e.g., outline purpose and method; identify sources of information; develop research tools such as surveys or questionnaires), ensuring that their plans follow guidelines for ethical research

D9132FB5F5CB4203893330BD3BA9B62F.description: Investigating: create research plans, and locate and select information relevant to their chosen topics, using appropriate social science research and inquiry methods;

F51D983654D64CFCA11F646D0CD48C32.description: formulate effective questions to guide their research and inquiry

538A1F7C78CF47C4B418623F88793851.description: identify key concepts (e.g., through discussion, brainstorming, use of visual organizers) related to their selected topics

06AFF9466FF5445D96AB3B64E4E3E094.description: explore a variety of topics related to child development and child rearing (e.g., infant and toddler nutrition, diverse child-rearing practices, community supports for parents and children) to identify topics for research and inquiry

72AB7EE1E76146FA8A54319DBE2B32BF.description: Exploring: explore topics related to child development and child rearing, and formulate questions to guide their research;
